seg.output:
Dear Brother, I will let you know how successfully the Lord Capito has conducted both the Synod and Megandri's business for us. In the meantime, I earnestly ask that my numerous letters to Zuinglium should be returned to you through the agency of Capito, as his brother Zuickii has informed the Constantiensians that their letters were returned. For I have written many things that could be twisted to a bad purpose by an ill-disposed reader. Therefore, I wish the severe edicts, by which our magistrates have abolished pensions, were recalled, should they still exist. But I could not express what a good end everything has come to. We never knew Capito before this time. We were 220 brothers assembled together for four days.
Send me the remaining part of my next letter, viz. an account of my studies, and how the place in Exodus about the hardening of Pharaoh's heart before the people is to be handled.
The brethren of the whole Synod send also their collection, which we commit to you and the Leonian brethren, ministers of the Word, to be distributed to those who are banished from Waggental and other places. Give us account who, and how many families there are, that we may, if we can, bestow something on them in their necessity.
The reason why the acts are not sent to Cristopher to be printed is this: because, as it is among all men, some had the word TON, they are bears' traces, which have no claws in the paper, and many other things of which I know well; by which Cristoffel, so honest and innocent in this matter, was suspected. Therefore, entreat that good man for me.
But by experience I have learned how honest and sincere your affection to me is, since you have answered so exactly to all. One thing I will always desire of you, which is that you burn what I have written concerning Megandri's cause.

seg.output:
I have learned through experience how sincere and faithful your attitude towards me is, since you have answered so accurately to everything. I want you to burn what I wrote about the matter of Megander. Finally, let me know if there are any annotations of Zuingli that should be printed.
Farewell and respond to this messenger of ours.
January 16th, Bern.
Your B. Haller.
I hear that Röllican is vying for the position among you. If he is accepted, let me know. For I fear that he will not be able to keep the position with us for long. No one would be more suitable than Röllican to restore the friendship between our two cities, and if he were to be sent to us, he could do much.
To my dearest brother Heinrich Bullinger, most learned preacher among the people of Zurich.

I have learned from experience how honest, faithful and sincere your attitude towards me is, since you answered so accurately to everything. This one thing I always ask of you, that you burn what I wrote about Megander's case. Lastly, you shall indicate whether there are any annotations of Zuinglius left to be printed.
Farewell and answer this letter of mine.
16th of January, Bern.
Your B. Hallerus.
I hear that Rellicanus is aspiring for the province among you. If he has been accepted, write. For I fear he may not be able to maintain the province with us for much longer. To my dearest brother Heinricus Bullinger, the most learned churchman among the people of Zurich.
